docs.lead_paragraph: A DEATH IN BELMONT By Sebastian Junger. Illustrated. 266 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $23.95.

headline.kicker: 'A Death in Belmont,' by Sebastian Junger

docs.abstract: Alan M Dershowitz reviews book A Death in Belmont by Sebastian Junger; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A builder who worked for Sebastian Junger's parents later claimed to be a serial killer. Did he murder their neighbor?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Buster's Law'' (editorial, April 2): In an attempt to clarify why this county is establishing a ''dangerous dog'' Web site, I ordered the stats on dog bites from the Westchester Department of Health. I expected to see a burgeoning explosion; instead, it showed the numbers are decreasing. So why do we need a registry?
docs.abstract: Animal Defenders of Westchester spokeswoman Kiley Blackman letter disputes April 2 editorial on 'dangerous' dogs in Westchester County

docs.lead_paragraph: The Tissue-Industrial Complex Anna O'Connell couldn't find Ted. She stood bent at the waist on a frigid afternoon last December, her head and all its fuzzy red hair crammed into an old stand-up freezer that looked like something you get milk from at the corner store: tall, white with a bit of rust and a pull handle. That freezer is the first thing you see when you walk into the Fox Chase Cancer Center laboratory in Philadelphia, where O'Connell has spent decades as a staff scientist. She pushed aside vial after vial. ''I know we still have him somewhere,'' she yelled, her head still inside the freezer. ''We've got serum from, like, 450,000 people.''
docs.abstract: Rebecca Skloot article on question of who owns blood and pieces of tissue that are routinely removed from Americans in course of any number of medical procedures and are used by scientists to develop everything from flu vaccines to penis-enlargement products; says that while scientists now have access to all the blood and tissues they want, growing number of activists--lawyers, ethicists, doctors and patients--are arguing cases and pushing for federal regulations that would grant people rights to control their tissues and profit from whatever uses they are put to; discusses litigation over Washington University's control over vast collection of prostate and blood samples that Dr William Catalona amassed while he worked at university, which is challenged by Catalona and many of his patients; drawings (L)
docs.snippet: Most of us have tissue or blood samples on file somewhere, but what we don't typically know is what research they are being used for and how much money is being made from them.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It's nice that Ben Stein has so many blessings to count (''First, Tame That Envy. Then Give Thanks,'' Everybody's Business, April 9).

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: What John Tierney doesn't mention is that if Ángel Espinoza should be deported in the event that the immigration bill passes, the American-born Mrs. Espinoza will face the prospect of being a single parent, presumably with mortgage payments.
docs.abstract: Larry Hoffman letter responds to John Tierney April 8 Op-Ed column; notes that if Angel Espinoza should be deported in event that immigration bill passes, American-born Mrs Espinoza will face prospect of being single parent

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal government has done such a miserable job of providing health insurance for the 46 million Americans who lack it that states around the country have been forced to step in with their own plans. The latest and boldest effort was signed into law this week in Massachusetts. It is a carefully crafted plan with elements that could serve as a model for elsewhere, provided Massachusetts finds sufficient funds to make it all work. The cornerstone of the program is a requirement that everyone have a health insurance policy or pay a financial penalty. States have long required drivers to carry liability insurance, but this is the first time any state has imposed a health insurance mandate.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that federal government has done such miserable job of providing health insurance for 46 million Americans who lack it that states around country have been forced to step in with their own plans; maintains that latest and boldest effort was signed into law in Massachusetts; holds that it is carefully crafted plan with elements that could serve as model for elsewhere, provided Massachusetts finds sufficient funds to make it work; notes that cornerstone of program is reqirement that everyone have health insurance policy or pay financial penalty; says Massachusetts deserves credit for tackling problem that Washington is failing to address
docs.snippet: The plan to provide everyone in Massachusetts with health insurance could serve as a model for elsewhere, provided Massachusetts finds sufficient funds to make it all work.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Illicit Poultry Smuggling May Aid Spread of Bird Flu There is increasing evidence that a thriving international trade in smuggled poultry -- including live birds, chicks and meat-- is helping spread bird flu, experts say. Poultry from bird-flu-infected countries has been banned in Europe but smuggling seriously undermines those bans, says Gen. Emilio Borghini, commander of the Military Police Health Service in Italy. A1 Berlusconi Suffers Setback Silvio Berlusconi's fight to remain prime minister of Italy suffered a possibly fatal blow, after the Interior Ministry announced that there were not enough contested ballots to overturn the thin victory of his challenger, Romano Prodi. A6 Iran Promises End to Israel President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran said that Israel is a ''constant threat'' and predicted that it was on the verge of ''being eliminated.'' A7 U.S. Program to Reshape Iran A new office of Iranian affairs in the State Department is poring over applications for a program to change the political process inside Iran. The plan, not yet approved by Congress, would include scholarships, exchange programs, radio and television broadcasts and other activities aimed at shaking up Iran's political system. A7 Israel Threatens Gaza Strip Israeli generals threatened to re-invade the Gaza Strip if Palestinian rocket attacks continued, keeping up a war of words and weapons even as Jews, Muslims and Christians celebrated their holy days. A7 Tensions Mount in Africa With the unrest in Sudan's Darfur region spreading into neighboring countries, Chad broke off relations with Sudan and threatened to oust 200,000 Sudanese refugees after staving off a rebel incursion into its sand-strewn capital. A3 NATIONAL A9-11 Bush Supports Rumsfeld, Despite Generals' Critique President Bush offered his full support to Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld in an effort to quell widening calls from retired generals who have urged that Mr. Rumsfeld resign his post. A1 Ruling on Arrests of Homeless A three-judge federal appeals court panel ruled that arresting homeless people for sleeping, sitting or lying on sidewalks and other public property when other shelter is not available was cruel and unusual punishment. The ruling essentially invalidates a Los Angeles ordinance. A9 Professor to Be Deported Federal authorities have decided to deport a former Florida professor and Palestinian rights activist, who was indicted in 2003, after failing to convict him on charges he helped finance terror attacks in Israel. A10 Bushes Report 2005 Income The president and Laura Bush reported adjusted gross income of $735,180 for last year and paid federal income taxes of $187,768, slightly less than in 2004, according to a copy of the couple's 2005 return released by the White House. A10 Lawmakers Pressured at Home As Democrats and Republicans remain at an impasse over immigration proposals, business lobbies and trade groups have turned to their grass-roots partners to put hometown pressure on lawmakers during their Congressional recess. A11 EDUCATION Law Segregates Schools Nebraska's only African-American state senator has helped the Legislature pass a law that will divide Omaha public schools into three racially identifiable districts, one largely black, one white and one Hispanic. A9 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 U.S. Terrorist Victims Sue Banks for Aid to Hamas Some 50 Americans, either survivors or relatives of people killed in terrorist attacks while in Israel, have filed multimillion-dollar suits in federal court in Brooklyn against three prominent international banks they say helped channel funds to Hamas. A1 Agent Was Cleared in 1976 Thirty years ago, a retired F.B.I. agent, R. Lindley DeVecchio, now charged with aiding in mob murders was accused of selling handguns to undercover officers. In a decision made largely by a young attorney named Rudolph Giuliani, who was the top aide to the deputy United States attorney general, the case was discarded, the federal prosecutor who handled it says. B1 Beliefs B6 SPORTSSATURDAY D1-6 Whispers Grow, Bonds is Silent The embattled Barry Bonds ignored reporters who descended upon him in Los Angeles as the San Francisco Giants prepared to play the Dodgers. Bonds was a bigger story than the game because he faced new questions about a federal grand jury investigating him for perjury. D1 ARTS B7-16 A Hit Show for Beckett at 100 In the surprise hit show of Ireland's monthlong festival celebrating Samuel Beckett, who was born on April 13 100 years ago, the star does not say a word. The popularity of ''Eh Joe,'' a relatively unknown 1965 script, has been one of many pleasant revelations during a month in Dublin where Beckett is inescapable. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-7 Exxon C.E.O. Pay Criticized Despite Exxon's formidable performance, some experts and consumer groups were surprised by the compensation given to Lee R. Raymond, the company's chief executive. A1 Toyota May Expand South Toyota is considering four Southern states for the site of its eighth North American assembly plant, the latest move in an expansion that could make it the world's biggest car company, people involved in Toyota's decision said. C1 Delta and Pilots Union Agree Delta Air Lines and the union representing its 6,000 pilots reached a tentative agreement on pay concessions, averting a possible strike. C3 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Mandatory health insurance; recipe for a perfect crisis; deaf theater; Eleanor Randolph on a cat rescue. Column: Maureen Dowd. Bridge B14 Crossword B14 Obituaries A14 TV Listings B16 Weather C8
